Award.AwardTitle: Flying With Swallows: A Project to Improve STEM Education at Moreno Valley College and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Moreno Valley College of the Riverside Community College District has received an NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources Design and Development tier award for a project entitled Flying With Swallows, which will integrate undergraduate research experiences and activities into the curricula of Biology and Chemistry courses at the institution. The subject of the multi-disciplinary research studies will be cliff swallows (Petrochelidon pyrrhonota) that migrate to the area from South or Central America to breed. The abundance of the swallows on campus during the breeding season will engage the interest of the student community. Flying With Swallows will follow two lines of investigation. The Ecosystem Survey will monitor the presence of all birds, with an emphasis on cliff swallows, as well as mammals, reptiles, and insects on the campus. This year-round data collection will generate a dynamic "living" map available on the college website. The Ecosystem Investigation will study the environmental impact of human activity on the swallow population. The swallows will be used as monitoring organisms in biological magnification studies. Students will conduct analyses of a variety of samples for the presence of pollutants and potentially pathogenic microorganisms.

Flying With Swallows is based on the research literature demonstrating that undergraduate research experiences have a positive impact on the persistence of STEM students to graduation. The FWS research experience will be aligned with the expected student learning outcomes for the biology and chemistry courses to ensure that students are acquiring the necessary disciplinary content knowledge, while enhancing their global awareness and critical thinking and communication skills. Project evaluation will include monitoring student progress, as well as surveys and interview procedures to inform future development of the project. The results of these evaluations will expand knowledge of best practices for the infusion of undergraduate research into the curricula of colleges and universities nationwide, but will be particularly relevant for the integration of undergraduate research into the curricula of community colleges, Hispanic Serving Institutions, and other Minority Serving Institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Flying With Swallows project (FWS) provided a platform to develop a multi-year research-based learning initiative that offered biology and chemistry students (approximately 250 annually) participation in scientific research on subjects that are familiar to them (cliff swallows that nest on the campus). This active learning approach lead to increases in: 1) the number of STEM student completions and transfers; 2) student retention rates; and 3) student success rates. 

FWS had two primary lines of inquiry: Ecosystem Survey and Ecosystem Investigation. As the result of the Ecosystem Survey activity, Moreno Valley College (MVC) now has five years of data (2015-2019) on cliff swallow population fluctuations in the surrounding area and on fauna captured by camera trapping. The database was created using ArcGIS software donated to the project by Esri (Environmental Systems Research Institute). The Ecosystem Investigation aspect of FWS involved biology students performing insect DNA barcoding to identify insects collected on the campus and consumed by swallows, and chemistry students measuring water and soil contents used by swallows to build their nests. Seventeen MVC students conducted individual research during the life of the FWS award which contributed to our understanding of cliff swallows.

All research projects were presented at conferences at the college, community, state and national levels by over twenty students.  The FWS project resulted in four publications about the educational value of undergraduate research and two research publications of interest to the scientific audience. The MVC swallow website was created at http://www.mvc.edu/swallows that is listed on the Academic Programs page under Undergraduate Research Initiatives. FWS participated in the 2019 STEM For All Video Showcase (sponsored by NSF #1642187 and TERC) where the video gained facilitator’s recognition as an undergraduate research project, and had 1,100 visits from 864 visitors from 174 locations from six continents (https://stemforall2019.videohall.com/presentations/1427).

General knowledge and curiosity about the nature and its uniqueness around MVC has been built among faculty, staff and students over the life of the FWS project. Math, geography, computer science, Spanish, anthropology, art and music faculty expressed their interest in collaborating with the project.  Cliff swallows became a subject MVC community talks about. FWS sponsored five MVC Annual Swallow Day events that included poster presentations from students participating in the project, Latin music with lyrics about swallows, and science seminars delivered by guest speakers from the University of Tulsa, California Wildlife Department, University of California, Riverside, and Esri (TED Talk speaker).  The project maintains collaborations with the scientific experts on swallows, local universities and wildlife organizations to enrich the experience for participating students and provide them with future opportunities to conduct research. Eight FWS students were invited to the paid 10-week Summer Research Institute at UCR, one student was invited to Hungary to participate in the paid 6-week International Summer Research Experience. The first MVC student ever admitted to an IVY league college, University of Pennsylvania, did so thanks to, as she stated, her research experience. 

The FWS project provided research-training opportunities for students that positively impact their future. According to the external evaluator of the project, over time, students became more comfortable and more confident in their coursework and in the research process. By studying real life subjects, students were given more freedom, promoting critical and creative thinking; with a hands-on approach, students felt more in-tune with nature and their surrounding environment. As a result, many students became more eager and excited to conduct research, approaching their natural surroundings with a new sense of curiosity, which most students agreed they would not experience in standard courses.
